title: With Time Running Out, ​E.U. Reveals ​Openness to a No-Deal Brexit

title: Becerra Supports ‘Medicare for All,’ and Could Help States Get There

content: Xavier Becerra has long supported moving the United States to a “Medicare for all” system. As President-elect Joe Biden’s pick to run Health and Human Services, he may have opportunities to speed up such a transition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: How Washington and Silicon Valley Agree to Disagree on Taming Big Tech
description: A group of experts gathered to debate privacy, competition and what to do — if anything — about tech giants’ growing power.
content: Silicon Valley’s most successful companies have moved fast and amassed millions — and in some cases, billions — of users, while governments have slowly caught on to how these new digital businesses worked. Now, policymakers better understand the power that tech platforms gained by offering free services, which users pay for with data, and how these affect markets and society.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Biden Asks Congress to Grant Waiver for ‘Cool Under Fire’ Defense Pick
description: Senior Democrats appear willing to exempt Lloyd J. Austin III, a retired four-star general, from a law meant to protect civilian control of the military.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., on Wednesday praised Lloyd J. Austin III, his choice for secretary of defense, as “a leader of extraordinary courage, character, experience and accomplishment,” and asked Congress to grant the exemption the retired four-star Army general needs from a law that bars officers recently on active duty from serving in the top Pentagon post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosa Lyster
title: Watch This Disgusting Food Video Right Now. It Explains Everything.
description: A viral clip of a grotesque breakfast dish reveals more about the way we use social media — and how it uses us — than about American cuisine.
content: The video makes it all seem so easy, even fun, and yet with each successive step, your sense of dread only mounts. First, you take an enormous brick of vividly orange cheese, one with enough structural integrity to allow you to hack into it with a knife. A cartoon mouse bounces up to encourage you, and to remind you of the longstanding cultural ties between cheese and mice. The jaunty, royalty-free music chirps away in the background as you ably carve out a deep recess within the cheese block, making sure the bottom is smooth. Then you place the block on top of four overlapping tortillas and wrap the cheese, sort of like a Christmas present. Strips of bacon are then applied until it is fully encased, and you slide the block into an oven preheated to 350. A little cartoon cat pops up to remind you that ovens are hot. After half an hour, you take the block out of the oven and you tie a sturdy strip of tinfoil around it. Then, you take —
source.name: The New York Times

title: Airlines Gear Up to Transport Vaccines That Could Revive Travel
description: Planes are one part of an elaborate supply chain to move billions of doses of vaccines around the world.
content: Months before anyone knew which of the coronavirus vaccine candidates would pull ahead or when they’d be available, airlines were trying to figure out how to transport doses around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Small Axe’ Review: The Agonies and Ecstasies of Black British Lives
description: Steve McQueen’s anthology of five films is a revelatory look at Afro-Caribbean neighborhoods in Britain from the 1960s to the ’80s.
content: When the British filmmaker Steve McQueen conceived the five films he collectively named “Small Axe,” he could not have foreseen the drastically disrupted world into which they would be released — a world that could shift, and perhaps intensify, the impact with which they would land.
source.name: The New York Times

content: For Tee Tran, the golden rule is not just an aspiration. It’s a way of life that he has tried to embody, particularly during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: The Work Diary of Mira Mariah, Tattoo and ‘Girl Culture’ Expert

content: In an ideal world, Mira Mariah would always be celebrating.

title: ‘These Girls Are Being Cut and Married in Droves’
description: In Samburu County, economic and social strife from the pandemic is helping turn a generation of girls into commodities.
content: A deep, sonorous melody pierces the night sky when young Samburu warriors celebrate an impending marriage. These songs, which echo across the arid plains of rural northern Kenya, are beautiful. They also often herald danger for girls in the region’s pastoralist communities — and during the coronavirus pandemic, they’ve grown alarmingly more frequent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Moity
title: Where Are Your Papers? A New Yorker Goes Home to Locked-Down France
description: I muddled through the worst of the pandemic in New York. The restrictions in France proved far more onerous.
content: SACLAY, France — Where are my keys, my wallet, my face mask, my backup face mask? Do I have my ID? Have I filled out paperwork describing where I’m going, and when, and why? Is my destination legal? Can I make it back in three hours or less?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: 20 Albums That Put a New Spin on the Holidays
description: Standards? Sure! But a crop of seasonal records from Dolly Parton, Tinashe and others introduce fresh original songs, too.
content: Mariah Carey’s modern classic “All I Want for Christmas Is You” finally hit No. 1 (after 25 years) last holiday season, surely inspiring more songwriters to try their hand at a well-worn but welcome annual tradition. Our pop and jazz critics surveyed the latest releases and picked out 20 that offer worthy additions to your seasonal playlists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Boris Johnson Once Mocked the Eurocrats of Brussels. They Haven’t Forgotten.
description: As a newspaper reporter decades ago, he made plenty of enemies there with his inflammatory articles. Now, those officials may determine his political fate.
content: LONDON — Three decades ago, an enterprising young foreign correspondent named Boris Johnson reported that the European Commission planned to blow up Berlaymont, its hulking, asbestos-riddled headquarters in Brussels. “Sappers will lay explosive charges at key points,” he wrote in The Daily Telegraph.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: The Best Thrillers of 2020
description: Which books proved most spine-tingling in this momentous nail-biter of a year?
content: A new Tana French is always cause for celebration, even when it doesn’t feature the textured, compromised detectives from the fictional Dublin Murder Squad. THE SEARCHER (Viking, 451 pp., $27), French’s second stand-alone book, stars a weary retired cop who has fled his old life in Chicago for the quiet obscurity of rural Ireland. That is, until he is thrust headlong into a new mystery that will require all his emotional acumen as well as his skills as a policeman. Read it once for the plot; read it again for the beauty and subtlety of French’s writing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Stenquist
title: Smarter Traffic Lights, Calmer Commuters
description: Advances in technology may come to a corner near you, easing traffic and possibly helping the environment.
content: How often have you cursed out a traffic light that took forever to change? Or the lights on a long stretch of road made you stop at every cross street, just when you felt you might actually make it to work on time? Take heart: Less painful commutes may be ahead, with advanced electronic control systems that apply artificial intelligence to the task of keeping traffic moving.

content: Members of The New York Times Food department come across hundreds of new recipes every year, and these are the recipes they can’t live without during the holidays. It was tough to pick just one recipe — most suggested a few — but the most common themes were latkes and, unsurprisingly, cookies of all kinds. Here are some of their favorites.

content: HOUSTON — The PGA Tour does not have a 72-hole stroke play event this week, and several weekend college football games, including the marquee matchup between Michigan and Ohio State, have been canceled or postponed because of the coronavirus, leaving the best female golfers in the world well positioned to fill the TV viewing void.

author: By Kim Tingley
title: We Know How to Curb the Pandemic. How Do We Make People Listen?
description: Could better public health messaging persuade more people to change their behavior?
content: At this point, we have all the scientific information we need in order to prevent the surgings of the coronavirus: Avoid gathering indoors with people from outside your household, keep physically apart from others, wear a mask, wash your hands often. Among those who can follow these precautions — a lot of people, as policymakers should recognize, can’t afford to — too many are still disregarding public health advice. A recent report by researchers from Northeastern University and elsewhere found that the number of Americans heeding most recommendations has dropped steadily since April. (Mask-wearing, which has increased, was an exception.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paige McClanahan
title: The Newest Challenge for Europe’s Parks: A Surge of New Nature Lovers
description: Lockdown-weary city dwellers across the continent are visiting parks and other protected areas for the first time, overwhelming staff and generating pleas for more support.
content: Lockdown-weary Europeans have sought out nature in record-breaking numbers this year, putting sudden and substantial pressure on national parks and other natural areas across the continent.

content: Early in Ryan Murphy’s “The Prom,” a Broadway flack starts reading the reviews of a newly opened show about Eleanor Roosevelt, “Eleanor!” The gang’s all here, including the self-adoring stars, Dee Dee Allen (Meryl Streep) and Barry Glickman (James Corden). The drinks and laughs are flowing, and everyone is as lit as their bedazzled outfits. And then the flack starts reading the notice from The New York Times (hiss, boo). “This is not a review you want when you have crappy advance sales,” he bleats. “This is going to close us.”

content: Airbnb priced its initial public offering on Wednesday at $68 a share, selling 51.5 million shares for $3.5 billion and valuing the home rental company at $47 billion. It is the largest I.P.O. of the year.It was a far higher price than the company had originally set, indicating investor demand for the stock. Airbnb had initially put its price range at $44 to $50 a share, and on Monday it had raised that to $56 to $60 each.

title: The Virus Has Stolen Your Face From Me
description: As a portrait artist, all I can do now is reconstruct the mysteries of who you are under the mask.
content: Today’s sightings: red paisley mask, pleated pink flowered mask, black VOTE mask, yellow smiley-face mask, Etsy bedazzled mask, Spiderman mask. Lots of surgical-blue paper masks. A few hard-shell N95s. One or two navy bandit gaiters. (Me, I’m under the grinning-wolf mask.) source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Pérez-Peña
title: How a Long Insurgency Plays Into Trump’s Move on Morocco
description: The 45-year-old fight between Morocco and separatists in Western Sahara threatens to return to outright war. By recognizing Moroccan sovereignty, the U.S. has taken sides for the first time.
content: President Trump’s decision to endorse Moroccan control of Western Sahara puts the United States once again at odds with world opinion, as it takes sides for the first time in a decades-long struggle at a moment when that conflict threatens to return to open warfare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shafia Zaloom
title: Kids Are Watching Pornography. Here’s How to Talk About It.
description: I teach sex ed. In light of a recent report on exploitation of children on the site Pornhub, I have some talking points for parents.
content: The New York Times columnist Nicholas Kristof’s recent report on videos of child sexual abuse on the website Pornhub may have parents wondering if their own children are watching Pornhub, or other pornography websites. Others may be appalled by the possibility that their child may view videos of assault and rape, or ask for or send sexually explicit selfies that could end up on social media or a porn site.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Morocco joins a list of Arab nations to begin normalizing relations with Israel.
description: Morocco has agreed to begin normalizing relations with Israel, becoming the fourth Arab state this fall to do so, the White House announced on Thursday.
content: Morocco has agreed to begin normalizing relations with Israel, becoming the fourth Arab state this fall to do so, the White House announced on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kai-Fu Lee
title: Give the A.I. Economy a Human Touch
description: Embracing artificial intelligence can help us create a new, equitable social contract — but only if we remember what makes us human.
content: This is an article from Turning Points, a special section that explores what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Masks, Distancing — and Tests
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Reducing the spread of Covid-19 over the next several months — while vaccines are being distributed — has the potential to save more than 100,000 American lives, as I explained earlier this week. So how can we reduce the spread?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Lebanon Prime Minister Charged With Negligence in Beirut Blast
description: An investigating judge named the caretaker prime minister, Hassan Diab, a suspect, a significant step toward holding the top levels of power accountable in the August explosion that killed 200.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Lebanese judge investigating the massive explosion in the port of Beirut has charged the acting prime minister, Hassan Diab, and three former ministers with negligence in the August blast that killed nearly 200 people, the state-run National News Agency reported on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Through the Night’ Review: Tucking In Children When Their Parents Can’t
description: A new documentary looks at a 24-hour day care center a couple runs in their home.
content: The lean and powerful documentary “Through The Night” centers on Dee’s Tots Childcare, a day care center in New Rochelle, N.Y., that provides 24-hour service for local families. Deloris and Patrick Hogan run the center out of their home seven days a week. In family fashion, the kids call Patrick Pop Pop, and everyone calls Deloris Nunu.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually.
content: In normal times, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater would now be encamped at New York City Center for the month, inspiring awe and bringing joy. This year, everything is virtual: a mix of archival and newly filmed video, supplemented with conversations, available free on the company’s website, YouTube channel and Facebook page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Coronavirus Vaccines Were Developed in Record Speed. Now, the Hard Part.
description: Don’t squander this opportunity, America.
content: The Food and Drug Administration is expected to grant emergency use authorizations to the first two coronavirus vaccines in the next several days. The sheer speed with which doctors and scientists were able to reach this stage is a major achievement, and the early results for both vaccines are undeniably impressive. New vaccines normally take years to develop, and scientists initially worried.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: Under the Mask, the Next Batman Will Be Black
description: In a new comic written by John Ridley, who wrote “12 Years a Slave,” the new Batman will be revealed as Tim Fox, the son of a business associate of Bruce Wayne.
content: Fans of DC Comics have been told for months that a new Batman will premiere in January. They were also teased that underneath the costume of the new caped crusader would likely be a person of color. The identity of the new hero was revealed on Thursday when DC released a cover of the second issue of the new comic: he is Timothy Fox, one of the sons of Lucius Fox, a business associate of Bruce Wayne, the original Batman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Fighters Win Key Ruling in Case That Could Upend U.F.C.’s Business
description: A judge said he would grant class-action status to a group of fighters arguing that the Ultimate Fighting Championship suppresses pay. If the fighters win, it could force the U.F.C. to pay much, much more.
content: A federal judge said on Thursday that he would make an important procedural ruling in favor of a group of mixed martial artists who are suing the Ultimate Fighting Championship, accusing it of abusing monopoly power to suppress fighter pay. The lawsuit, which will be granted class action status, could eventually cost the U.F.C. billions of dollars, fundamentally alter the world of mixed martial arts and establish new antitrust case law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: End of ‘One Day at a Time’ Removes One of TV’s Few Latino Families
description: After being canceled last year by Netflix, the sitcom, a reboot of a Norman Lear classic, found a new but short-lived home on cable.
content: The sitcom “One Day at a Time,” about a multigenerational Cuban-American household, has had a complicated plotline of its own. When Netflix canceled the show last year after three seasons, it was rescued by a cable network, at least in part because of the outcry from its small but passionate fan base.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ismail Alfa and Ruth Maclean
title: Executed Nigerian Farmers Were Caught Between Boko Haram and the Army
description: More than 70 agricultural workers were killed by militants, who accused them of telling the authorities that the extremist group was in the area.
content: ZABARMARI, Nigeria — For years, the farmers had an agreement with Boko Haram militants: They could tend their fields in peace, as long as they did not report the fighters’ presence to the Nigerian Army.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: Airbnb Tops $100 Billion on First Day of Trading, Reviving Talk of a Bubble
description: The home-rental company’s blockbuster I.P.O. followed that of the delivery company DoorDash. Investors piled into both.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Over the last decade, Airbnb has upended the travel industry, riled regulators, frustrated local communities and created a mini-economy of short-term rental operators, all while spinning a warm narrative of belonging and connection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Once and Future Handbag
description: Predictions that 2020 would bring the end of the bag have been greatly exaggerated.
content: In a case of truly unfortunate timing, the week before the Victoria and Albert Museum’s blockbuster show celebrating all things bag related — an exhibition over 18 months in the making, one of the largest ever in a museum, with loans from around the world — was to have opened on April 25, Britain shut down in response to the coronavirus. The show was postponed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Merkel, Facebook, Ethiopia: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Old worlds spring to life in this week’s recommended titles, from a scientific account of Neanderthal culture to a biography of the seminal American foodie James Beard. There’s a new edition of “The Babur Nama,” the diaries of the 16th-century warlord who founded the Mughal dynasty in India. A look back at the golden age of Egyptology starting in 1822 — which is to say, a look back at archaeologists looking (way) back. A biography of the modernist poet and painter Max Jacob, and one of Eleanor Roosevelt, and a novel set in Britain in the decades after World War II. And there’s a reissue of Susan Taubes’s 1969 novel, “Divorcing,” which itself has much to say about history and the passage of time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: N.F.L. Week 14 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread
description: The Dolphins face their biggest test yet in the Chiefs and the Steelers, after an 11-0 start, are trying to avoid a losing streak.
content: The N.F.L. made its way through a few weeks of odd schedules caused by coronavirus delays, and appears set for its first “normal” week in a while. Or at least the league is starting out with that plan until any virus-related adjustments are needed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: States Try to Rescue Small Businesses as U.S. Aid Is Snarled
description: State governments are offering loans, grants and tax rebates, but budget constraints limit their impact.
content: With the economic recovery faltering and federal aid stalled in Washington, state governments are stepping in to try to help small businesses survive the pandemic winter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green, Luke Broadwater and Stacy Cowley
title: Student Loan Cancellation Sets Up Clash Between Biden and the Left
description: Democratic leaders are pressing the president-elect to cancel $50,000 in debt per student borrower by fast executive action, but he wants Congress to pass more modest relief.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is facing pressure from congressional Democrats to cancel student loan debt on a vast scale, quickly and by executive action, a campaign that will be one of the first tests of his relationship with the liberal wing of his party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: Housing Fights to Be Heard in the Mayoral Race
description: A coalition of housing groups releases a blueprint that includes rezoning affluent neighborhoods, legalizing basement apartments and turning hotels into affordable housing.
content: In a New York mayoral race already transformed by the pandemic and mounting racial justice issues, a coalition of more than 80 wide-ranging organizations has released a report to remind the crowded field: Don’t forget about housing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: As Trump Disputes Election Results, Republicans Target Voting by Mail
description: Nearly half of voters cast absentee ballots in the election, a huge increase. If Republicans have their way, that might not last.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s barrage of losses in court cases trying to undermine the election has not stopped Republicans from turning to battles they might be able to win — attempts to limit or undermine the future use of the vote-by-mail ballots that so infuriated Mr. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Shane Goldmacher
title: Team of Rivals? Biden’s Cabinet Looks More Like a Team of Buddies
description: In making his picks for the new administration, the president-elect has put a premium on personal relationships.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has worked with the former aide he wants to be secretary of state since their time at the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in the 1990s. His nominee for agriculture secretary endorsed his first presidential bid more than 30 years ago. And he knows his choice for Pentagon chief from the retired general’s time in Iraq, where Mr. Biden’s son Beau, a military lawyer, also served on the general’s staff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Phil Linz, Unlikely Baseball Celebrity, Is Dead at 81
description: Never a star and rarely a starter as a Yankee in the 1960s, Linz made news not for playing baseball but for playing the harmonica.
content: Phil Linz played on three World Series teams with the Yankees in the 1960s and spent seven seasons in the major leagues.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Jerry Seinfeld Rarely Laughs While He’s Reading
description: “The written word is tough.”
content: “It’s pretty hard to laugh when you’re reading — the written word is tough,” says the comedian and author of “Is This Anything?” But he makes an exception for John Updike: “You know, describing the circles of water under someone’s toes when they get out of the pool. That makes me laugh more than anything, that he would zero in on that.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Wild Mountain Thyme’ Review: Finding Love Down on the Farm
description: John Patrick Shanley adapts his play “Outside Mullingar” into a movie. (Don’t worry about the accents.)
content: Whenever a movie has its performers speak in a regional dialect, the world entire suddenly teems with accent experts. “Wild Mountain Thyme,” written and directed by John Patrick Shanley (adapted from his play “Outside Mullingar”) is set in Ireland. And it started getting pushback in that country when its trailer dropped in November. Film people on social media made sport with the speaking styles of its American, English and Irish cast too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judge John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Plush Toy Nativity Scene Advent Calendars
description: It’s the most wonderful time of the year — until mom tries to hijack your Balthazar.
content: Michelle writes: My family has a plush Advent calendar that forms a Nativity scene. For years, my sister (20) and I (23) have alternated who gets to add the wise man Balthazar, the most special plush in the calendar. Now our mom wants to add Balthazar herself. She’s never participated before. Please stop her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Civilian Control of the Military Is Vital
description: Biden must give a better explanation for why a waiver is justified and how to stop this from becoming a trend.
content: Joe Biden ran for the White House promising to restore the norms that protect American democracy, which had badly eroded under President Trump. Among the most worrisome is the erosion of the principle that the military should be led by a civilian and those in uniform kept separate from partisan politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: To Deter Iranian Attacks on U.S. Troops, Pentagon Orders B-52 Flights to Middle East
description: It was the second time in three weeks that Air Force bombers had conducted long-range flights near Iranian air space on short notice.
content: WASHINGTON — Two American B-52 bombers flew a show-of-force mission in the Persian Gulf on Thursday that military officials said was intended to deter Iran and its proxies from carrying out attacks against United States troops in the Middle East amid rising tensions between the two countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Manuel Álvarez
title: They Call Us Enemies of the Cuban People
description: The San Isidro movement is a small step toward a national conversation.
content: HAVANA — I have been on the news on Cuban television twice in my life. The first time, I was a happy 10-year-old boy, shaking hands with Fidel Castro. The second time was just a few days ago, when television reports described me as someone who is “openly hostile toward Cuba” — an enemy of my country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh and Gillian R. Brassil
title: U.S. Will Not Punish Olympic Athletes for Peaceful Protests
description: Breaking from International Olympic Committee guidelines, the United States Olympic and Paralympic Committee announced it would not penalize athletes who participate in demonstrations.
content: The United States Olympic and Paralympic Committee announced on Thursday that it would no longer punish athletes who participate in peaceful protests, such as kneeling or raising a fist at a medal ceremony, putting itself in direct conflict with the longstanding policy of the International Olympic Committee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Wines to Remember in a Year to Forget
description: Travel, restaurants and vineyards were all virtually off limits. But a lot of bottles were opened at home, creating a different sort of history.
content: Like many people, I’ve spent most of 2020 sitting at home thinking about what was to have been.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: E.U.’s Top Drug Regulator Says It’s ‘Fully Functional’ After Cyberattack
description: The agency’s leader said the breach would not delay delivery of a coronavirus vaccine to member nations.
content: The European Union’s top drug regulator, whose approval is necessary for countries of the bloc to begin rolling out the coronavirus vaccine, has begun an investigation after it was hit by a cyberattack, the head of the agency said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Gunda’ Review: A Remarkable Pig’s-Eye View of the World
description: This astonishing documentary offers an intimate look at the lives of a sow, her rambunctious piglets, a one-legged chicken and a herd of cows.
content: What do filmmakers see when they look at animals? Not much, apparently: For the most part, animals in movies are atmospheric background — a solitary cat in a window, a horse in a field glimpsed from a car. Occasionally they are symbols, like the many sacrificed bunnies of cinema (“The Rules of the Game” et al.). At other times, animals are cast as favorite companions, and plenty of dogs have played good boy onscreen. Yet even in films as distinct as “Old Yeller” and “Best in Show,” animals are usually in service to the human story, to our feelings and tears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘Farewell Amor’ Review: Alone Together
description: Ekwa Msangi’s tender drama shows us that goodbyes haunt immigrants wherever they go.
content: Contrary to its title, “Farewell Amor” begins with a reunion. In a delicate opening set in an airport, Walter (Ntare Guma Mbaho Mwine), an Angolan refugee in New York, embraces his wife and teenage daughter, who’ve just arrived in America after a 17-year wait for visas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Dec. 16, 2020
description: Which of these six skills would you choose to instantly master? How does your answer compare to what these Times subscribers said?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: How Do I Tell My Relatives to Stop Buying Me Christmas Gifts?
description: I’m tired of tossing useless presents, especially since I put so much time into shopping for my family.
content: How can I ask my brother and sister-in-law not to give me a gift for Christmas? She does the shopping for their family, and while I know it’s the thought that counts, her presents are never to my taste or things I can use. (Some also appear to be regifts.) So, I donate them to charity shops or throw them away. This seems like a waste of their money, and I’m tired of recycling their gifts. I always spend a great deal of time choosing gifts that I think each member of their large extended family will like. But I feel less joy in it every year. Any thoughts?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: How We Followed a 1,500-Mile Migration Journey
description: Over several months, a team of Times journalists tracked the progress of a pregnant mother displaced by the pandemic.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: The New Abortion Rights Advocates Are on TikTok
description: Gen Z activists have been unapologetic and confrontational, a shift in tactics for a movement at a crossroads.
content: In a TikTok filmed in August outside of a women’s health center in Charlotte, N.C., the uncensored version of the mid-1990s novelty rap song “Short, Short Man,” by Gillette blares: “Eenie weenie teenie weenie shriveled little short, short man.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘The Weasels’ Tale’ Review: House Hunting
description: Argentine showbiz stars in a remote mansion battle with two real estate hustlers in Juan José Campanella’s crowd-pleasing comedy.
content: Schemers meet their match in “The Weasels’ Tale,” Juan José Campanella’s crowd-pleasing Argentine comedy. A former diva, Mara (grande dame Graciela Borges), shares a rambling remote mansion with her milquetoast husband, Pedro (Luis Brandoni), and two suave parasites she used to make movies with: a director, Norberto (Oscar Martínez), and a screenwriter, Martín (Marcos Mundstock). They pass the time trading reminiscences and barbs, until a slick city couple, Bárbara (Clara Lago) and Francisco (Nicolás Francella), show up and angle to buy the property.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Deb Price, a First as a Columnist on Gay Life, Dies at 62
description: If she wrote for mainstream Americans about same-sex couples in everyday situations, she thought, society would have a harder time denying them equal rights.
content: As the nation’s first nationally syndicated lesbian columnist who wrote regularly about gay life, Deb Price certainly covered pointed issues, like the debate over gay people in the military.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Movie Theaters Are Dying. Did Jason Kilar Deal the Final Blow?
description: The WarnerMedia C.E.O. was trying to drag Hollywood into the 21st century, but now he’s at odds with the theaters and filmmakers he needs on his side.
content: If you want to be the first to watch “Dune,” “Godzilla vs. Kong” or the new “Matrix” movie this year (yes, there’s a fourth one) — you won’t have to line up at a movie theater. That’s because Jason Kilar, the C.E.O. of WarnerMedia, announced last week that the full slate of Warner Bros. films will be simultaneously released in theaters and on the company’s streaming service, HBO Max.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Backs Muslim Men in Case on No-Fly List
description: The court also dismissed a challenge to Delaware’s court system, which takes account of judges’ partisan ties to create ideological balance.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday ruled in favor of three Muslim men who say they were put on the no-fly list in retaliation for refusing to become government informants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Harmon
title: The virus spreads at wildfire speed in tiny Rhode Island, surpassing rates of new cases elsewhere.
description: Rhode Island, the smallest U.S. state in area, now has the fastest spread of coronavirus, with more new cases per capita being reported than any other state, according to a New York Times database.
content: Rhode Island, the smallest U.S. state in area, now has the fastest spread of coronavirus, with more new cases per capita being reported than any other state, according to a New York Times database.

content: Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, is testifying on Thursday before the Congressional Oversight Commission, a bipartisan panel tasked with overseeing how pandemic aid is distributed, about his management of stimulus funds.

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Truck Driver Crashes Into Cyclists, Killing 5, Outside Las Vegas
description: The crash happened on Thursday morning as a group of about 20 bicyclists rode on the shoulder of U.S. 95 in Clark County, just north of Searchlight, Nev.
content: It was an annual tradition, a 130-mile ride on long stretches of highway from the M Resort Spa Casino in Henderson, Nev., through Searchlight to Nipton, Calif., and back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Opam
title: Surfer Dies After Shark Attack in Hawaii
description: The 56-year-old man died a day after the attack in Maui. A surf competition scheduled in the area later that day was postponed and moved.
content: A 56-year-old surfer died in Maui, Hawaii, on Wednesday night, one day after a shark had attacked him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Militia Leader Is Convicted in Bombing of a Minnesota Mosque
description: Prosecutors said Michael Hari had helped to bomb the Dar Al Farooq Islamic Center in Bloomington in 2017 to try to terrorize Muslims and scare them into leaving the country.
content: A militia group leader who wanted to drive Muslims out of the United States was convicted on Wednesday of helping to bomb a Minnesota mosque in 2017, just as congregants began to gather for prayers, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: Jackson Pollock, Before the Drip
description: “Mural,” his largest painting, is back in New York for the first time in 20 years, at the Guggenheim.
content: For Jacques-Louis David it was “The Oath of the Horatii,” for Kazimir Malevich it was “Black Square,” for Virginia Woolf it was “Jacob’s Room,” for Amy Winehouse it was “Rehab.” These are the breakthrough works — the hinges between the early career and the mature one. Everything before them looks like a warm-up, everything after like a natural outcome, though at the moment of their creation, who could tell?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Trustbusters Come for Facebook. Finally.
description: The government decides to try to enforce antitrust laws.
content: Facebook, like other big tech firms, has sought to maintain its dominance, and to keep profits rolling in, by gobbling up any upstarts that have threatened its market power. The company’s view of competition can be summed up by an email sent in 2008 by its chief executive and founder, Mark Zuckerberg: “It is better to buy than compete.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: affectation
description: This word has appeared in 11 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Holidays in a pandemic? Here’s what happened in 1918.
description: The influenza pandemic of 1918-19, in which millions of Americans were sickened and 675,000 died, seemed to roll across the United States in waves, much like the coronavirus today. The winter holidays in 1918 were marked by grievous loss, and came during a relative lull after the deadliest wave, in the fall. Another, smaller surge would peak shortly after New Year’s Day.

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Inspector General Criticizes V.A.’s Handling of Sexual Assault Complaint
description: The inspector general’s report also expressed disappointment that the V.A. did not determine whether to take action “to provide a safer and more welcoming environment” for women at its facilities.
content: WASHINGTON — An inspector general inquiry has criticized Robert L. Wilkie, the secretary of veterans affairs, for a response that was “at a minimum unprofessional” after a female Navy veteran reported a sexual assault at a department hospital in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo and Claudia Gryvatz Copquin
title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: This weeks properties are a four-bedroom in Stockton, N.J., and a six-bedroom in Nissequogue, N.Y.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Senate Rejects Attempted Blockade of Weapons Sale to U.A.E.
description: The Senate endorsed the Trump administration’s last-minute push to sell a $23 billion arms package including armed drones and stealth fighter jets to the Emirati military.
content: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Wednesday rejected efforts to block the sale of munitions worth $23 billion to the United Arab Emirates, overcoming concerns about sending weapons to Gulf Arab nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: With Paris Theaters Closed, Church Is the Only Show in Town
description: Coronavirus restrictions have shut playhouses and concert halls. So our critic went to Mass to get her fix of music, choreography and drama.
content: PARIS — Where can you find elaborate costumes, choreographed flourishes and live music in France right now? Not in theaters. Since the country eased its second lockdown in late November, the show has resumed in only one setting: churches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Finding Yingying’ Review: Vanishing Point
description: This documentary about the search for a missing student in Illinois takes a compassionate approach to grim material.
content: The chilling documentary “Finding Yingying” watches a family grapple with an unfathomable horror: the disappearance and probable death of a loved one who was living far away. Yingying Zhang, a visiting scholar from China at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, went missing in June 2017. What happened with the investigation and in court can be found online, but most of the film deals with the dread-filled uncertainty before those outcomes, and with the continuing search for Zhang’s body.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fahim Abed
title: Afghan War Casualty Report: December 2020
description: At least 21 pro-government forces and eight civilians have been killed in Afghanistan so far this month.
content: At least 21 pro-government forces and eight civilians were killed in Afghanistan the past week. The deadliest attack took place in Balkh Province, where seven Afghan police officers were abducted by the Taliban and later killed. In Ghazni Province, the Taliban attempted to coordinate attacks on security bases in the Nano Baba area of Andar District. A military Humvee stolen by the Taliban and laden with explosives targeted a base, but it was hit by a rocket fired by Afghan forces. Three soldiers were killed and two others were wounded in the explosion. A second truck laden with explosives targeting another military base in the area was seized by Afghan forces, though the driver managed to escape from the area. A female journalist and her driver were shot and killed in Jalalabad, the provincial capital of Nangarhar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright and Lucy Tompkins
title: Covid-19 caused the sudden death of a top state lawmaker in New Hampshire.
description: The New Hampshire State Legislature was already fiercely divided over the coronavirus when the new Republican speaker of the House of Representatives, Richard Hinch, died suddenly on Wednesday. Then came the news on Thursday that the cause of his death was Covid-19.
content: The New Hampshire State Legislature was already fiercely divided over the coronavirus when the new Republican speaker of the House of Representatives, Richard Hinch, died suddenly on Wednesday. Then came the news on Thursday that the cause of his death was Covid-19.

title: Poem: the times
description: Lucille Clifton brings a complexity to something we imagined we understood — and a relentless honesty.
content: Aracelis Girmay has written that Lucille Clifton’s works are “explicitly historical and of a palpable present moment.” Clifton brings a complexity to something we imagined we understood — and a relentless honesty. Here, she admits, of the child who has killed and the child who has died, “i catch myself relieved that they are/white.” And yet, by poem’s end, she remembers that “these too are your children this too is your child.” The line she draws is always at being complicatedly human.
